Article.title: Voices: Like post-earthquake Nepal, Red God is in limbo
Article.Description: The god, stalled in the midst of its pilgrimage, symbolizes the plight of Nepal.
Article.MainBody: FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Voices: Like post-earthquake Nepal, Red God is in limbo Like more than 3 million Nepalis, the Red God is homeless. Since the 7.8 magnitude earthquake on April 25, his enormous wooden chariot, with its towering jute and vine spire, has been Post to Facebook Voices: Like post-earthquake Nepal, Red God is in limbo Like more than 3 million Nepalis, the Red God is homeless. Since the 7.8 magnitude earthquake on April 25, his enormous wooden chariot, with its towering jute and vine spire, has been Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1MfaH8u CancelSend A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 1 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Voices: Like post-earthquake Nepal, Red God is in limbo Donatella Lorch, Special for USA TODAY 5:26 p.m. EDT July 8, 2015 Like more than 3 million Nepalis, the Red God is homeless. Since the magnitude-7.8 earthquake on April 25, 2015, his enormous wooden chariot, with its towering jute and vine spire, has been parked, or rather stopped, in the middle of a street just up the road from where I live. The spire, leaning precipitously even before the earthquake, is secured with two heavy ropes tied to nearby trees. (Photo: Donatella Lorch) 82 CONNECT 78 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE LALITPUR, Nepal Like more than 3 million Nepalis, the Red God is homeless. Since the magnitude-7.8 earthquake on April 25, his enormous wooden chariot, with its towering jute and vine spire, has been parked, or rather stopped, in the middle of a street just up the road from where I live. The spire, leaning precipitously even before the earthquake, is secured with two heavy ropes tied to nearby trees. The god, known as the Rato Machhendranath, is never alone. There is always a Hindu or Buddhist priest sitting next to him in his tiny alcove, perched 10 feet above the street, and always two shotgun-toting police officers to guard him as well. Worshipers light butter lamps on the road below him and passersby on motorcycles slow down, touching their foreheads and then the huge carved and brightly painted wooden wheels, demonstrating 'puja' or prayer. The symbolism of this stalled chariot is not lost on many people in the Kathmandu Valley. In growing competition with a fast-encroaching modern world, this is a land of deep and complex religious rituals, an intricate mix of Hinduism and tantric Buddhism practiced by the Newars, the original inhabitants of the valley. Their traditional villages of brick and mud homes, dotting the area around Kathmandu, were hit hardest by the earthquake. The Red God's home is in Bungamati, a Newar village just south of Patan, Kathmandu's twin city. In just over 40 seconds, the April earthquake destroyed or badly damaged almost the entire village. The god's home, a temple in the main square, turned into a pile of rubble. "We have been stopped here for two months," said Shaunu Shakya, 65, a priest who is accompanying the Red God. "Never in the history of the festival has an earthquake come. The astrologers say we must complete our trip, but that we also cannot move until the aftershocks stop for at least four days." Machhendranath's limbo is very much Nepal's as it struggles to rebuild, its past damaged and its future uncertain. More than two months since the quake, it is slowly becoming clearer that the tremors, which continue on a daily basis, did more than just destroy homes. They are continuously influencing a way of life and thinking. For many, especially outside Kathmandu, it is a day-to-day struggle for food and shelter. Heavy monsoon rains are destabilizing the earthquakecracked mountains, and landslides have already begun to sweep away villages in the north and east of the country. The international community has committed more than $4 billion to help rebuild Nepal, but that complex work will only begin in early September. I've lived in Nepal for two years, and for much of that time, I had planned to be in Kathmandu for April 2015. This April was one of Nepal's most unique festivals, the storied Rato Machhendranath jatra, which occurs only once every 12 years. It is not only one of the largest and longest chariot festivals in the world, lasting two to four months depending on the determinations of local astrologers, but also a massive spectacle involving months of priestly rituals, many animal sacrifices, the construction of the chariot (by hand) and tens of thousands of spectators. The Red God isn't really much to look at. He is a smallish enigma, just over 3 feet tall, wrapped in shapeless cloth. Every year, a priest gives his flattish wide face a bright new coat of red paint. He is worshiped by both Hindus and Buddhists. He is all powerful, but humans can summon him at will. The event begins in Bungamati, about 8 kilometers south of Patan, where carpenter clans build the 6-foot-high wooden wheels from scratch, without nails, and vine lashers hand-tie a complex and thick weave of tree trunks, cane and vines into a 60-foot-high spire, called a 'rath.' The chariot is hand-pulled with thick ropes by hundreds of youths. On April 25, the rath was about 500 yards from our house. My son Lucas and I were invited to watch the afternoon pulling from the rooftop of a nearby house. An hour later, the earthquake hit Nepal. There are those who believe that the earthquake happened because the Red God's chariot was built without fully observing construction rituals. Many Nepalis do not believe in these superstitions. Yet there is a link between this festival and life in Nepal. The complexities involved in building and moving the chariot are emblematic of an old world of risk and contingency, where ancient rituals must be observed in an effort to ensure stability, if not progress, and where the line between triumph and disaster is often very fine. The earthquake brought communities together. Neighbors are helping neighbors. Many are living in transitional shelters, trying to get through the monsoons and the upcoming winter, until they have the means to rebuild their houses. The Red God's permanent temple will also need to be rebuilt, and he will need to live elsewhere while that happens. But he is not alone, and like many Nepalis, he and his devotees also show the tremendous resilience for which Nepal is famous. Lorch is a writer based in Nepal 82 CONNECT 78 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1MfaH8u TOP VIDEOS

Article.title: White House ready to let Iran talks continue indefinitely
Article.Description: GOP lawmakers say getting a good deal is more important than meeting a deadline.
Article.MainBody: White House ready to let Iran talks continue indefinitely An interim agreement in November 2013 required Iran to scale back its nuclear activities. Post to Facebook White House ready to let Iran talks continue indefinitely An interim agreement in November 2013 required Iran to scale back its nuclear activities. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1Mf1tco CancelSend A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 17 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs White House ready to let Iran talks continue indefinitely Oren Dorell , USA TODAY 12:38 p.m. EDT July 8, 2015 White House press secretary Josh Earnest answers a question on the Iran nuclear talks during the daily press briefing on July 7, 2015. (Photo: Evan Vucci, AP) 54 CONNECT 79 TWEET LINKEDIN 17 COMMENTEMAILMORE After missing two deadlines in a week, the White House may allow Iran nuclear talks to continue indefinitely under an interim agreement that already limits Iran's nuclear program. While the pressure of deadlines set for June 30 and Tuesday succeeded in squeezing important concessions from Iran, "we haven't gotten everything that we wanted yet," White House spokesman Josh Earnest said. "What we want to make sure of is that we continue to keep in place, an agreement that freezes Iran's nuclear program, rolls it back in some key areas, while we continue to have these conversations," he said. The negotiations in Vienna between Iran and six world powers the United States, Britain, France, Russia, China and Germany aim to curb Iran's nuclear program in return for lifting crippling U.S. and international sanctions on Tehran. Envoys now seek a conclusion by Friday. Secretary of State John Kerry, left, meets with his counterparts from world powers and Iran at nuclear talks in Vienna on July 6, 2015. (Photo: Joe Klamar, AFP/Getty Images) Each time a deadline for the talks is extended, the negotiators must agree to extend the date of the terms of the interim agreement reached in November 2013 . Iran's deputy foreign minister, Abbas Araqchi, told reporters in Vienna that Iran is not bound by any deadline and will stay in Vienna as long as it takes, but that there will be no months-long extension to the talks, according to Tasnim News Agency. Negotiators have made progress on several major sticking areas where the sides seemed far apart two weeks ago. These include tentative agreements by Iran to answer questions by the U.N. nuclear watchdog agency about past nuclear research, and to participate in a process for granting inspectors access to suspected civilian and military nuclear sites. Diplomats have also reached a tentative agreement on the timing for the lifting of sanctions, which Iran wants eliminated immediately and the United States wants lifted in stages as an agreement is implemented. Differences remain, however, on whether those sanctions will be suspended, as Western nations want, so they can be reimposed if Iran fails to meet terms of the agreement, or eliminated for good, as Iran would like.

Article.title: Boko Haram offers to swap kidnapped girls for detainees
Article.Description: Boko Haram's offer is limited to the girls taken in April 2014.
Article.MainBody: Boko Haram offers to swap kidnapped girls for detainees Boko Haram's offer is limited to the girls taken in April 2014. Post to Facebook Boko Haram offers to swap kidnapped girls for detainees Boko Haram's offer is limited to the girls taken in April 2014. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1Mf22CM CancelSend A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 5 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Boko Haram offers to swap kidnapped girls for detainees Michelle Faul, Associated Press 12:23 p.m. EDT July 8, 2015 The parents of children abducted by Boko Haram attend an event linked to the "Bring Back Our Girls" campaign at the presidential residence in Abuja, Nigeria, on July 8, 2015. (Photo: Olamikan Gbemiga, AP) 28 CONNECT 61 TWEET LINKEDIN 5 COMMENTEMAILMORE LAGOS, Nigeria (AP) Nigeria's Boko Haram extremists are offering to free more than 200 young women and girls kidnapped from a boarding school in the town of Chibok in exchange for the release of militant leaders held by the government, a human rights activist has told The Associated Press. The activist said Boko Haram's current offer is limited to the girls from the school in northeastern Nigeria whose mass abduction in April 2014 ignited worldwide outrage and a campaign to "Bring Back Our Girls" that stretched to the White House. The new initiative reopens an offer made last year to the government of former President Goodluck Jonathan to release the 219 students in exchange for 16 Boko Haram detainees, the activist said. The man, who was involved in negotiations with Boko Haram last year and is close to current negotiators, spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to talk to reporters on this sensitive issue. Fred Eno, an apolitical Nigerian who has been negotiating with Boko Haram for more than a year, told the AP that "another window of opportunity opened" in the last few days, though he could not discuss details. He said the recent slew of Boko Haram bloodletting some 350 people killed in the past nine days is consistent with past ratcheting up of violence as the militants seek a stronger negotiating position. Presidential adviser Femi Adesina said on Saturday that Nigeria's government "will not be averse" to talks with Boko Haram. "Most wars, however furious or vicious, often end around the negotiation table," he said. Eno said the 5-week-old administration of President Muhammadu Buhari offers "a clean slate" to bring the militants back to negotiations that had become poisoned by the different security agencies and their advice to Jonathan. Two months of talks last year led government representatives and Eno to travel in September to a northeastern town where the prisoner exchange was to take place, only to be stymied by the Department for State Service intelligence agency, the activist said. At the last minute, the agency said it was holding only four of the militants sought by Boko Haram, the activist said. It is not known how many Boko Haram suspects are detained by Nigeria's intelligence agency, whose chief Buhari fired last week. The activist said the agency continues to hold suspects illegally because it does not have enough evidence for a conviction, and any court would free them. Nigerian law requires charges be brought after 48 hours. Thousands of suspects have died in custody, and some detainees wanted by Boko Haram may be among them. Amnesty International alleges that 8,000 detainees have died in military custody some have been shot, some have died from untreated injuries due to torture, and some have died from starvation and other harsh treatment. In May, about 300 women, girls and children being held captive by Boko Haram were rescued by Nigeria's military, but none were from Chibok. It is believed that the militants view the Chibok girls as a last-resort bargaining chip. In that infamous abduction, 274 mostly Christian girls preparing to write science exams were seized from the school by Islamic militants in the early hours of April 15, 2014. Dozens escaped on their own in the first few days, but 219 remain missing. Boko Haram has not shown them since a May 2014 video in which its leader, Abubakar Shekau warned: "You won't see the girls again unless you release our brothers you have captured." In the video, nearly 100 of the girls, who have been identified by their parents, were shown wearing Islamic hijab and reciting the Quran. One of them said they had converted to Islam. International indignation at Nigeria's failure to rescue the girls was joined by U.S. first lady Michelle Obama. In a radio address in May 2014, she said she and President Barack Obama are "outraged and heartbroken" over the abduction. Jonathan's government initially denied there had been any mass abduction and delays of a rescue that might have brought the girls home became a hallmark of his other failures. He steadfastly refused to meet with the Bring Back Our Girls campaigners, charging they were politicizing the issue. On Wednesday, President Buhari welcomed those campaigners at the presidential villa in Abuja and pleaded "We only ask for your patience." He said "The delay and conflicting reaction by the former government and its agencies is very unfortunate." Campaign leader Oby Ezekwesili said, "The rescue of our Chibok girls is the strongest statement that this government could make to showg respect for the sanctity and dignity of every Nigerian life." There have been unconfirmed reports that some of the girls have been taken to neighboring countries, and that some have been radicalized and trained as fighters. At least three were reported to have died one from dysentery, one from malaria and one from a snake bite. Last year, Shekau said the girls were an "old story," and that he had married them off to his fighters. Lawan Zanna, whose daughter is among the captives, said this week that 14 Chibok parents have died since the mass kidnapping, many from stress-related illnesses blamed on the ordeal. Some of the Chibok girls who managed to escape have been rejected by their community and now live with family friends, tired of hearing taunts like "Boko Haram wives." The assumption that all girls and women held by the group have been raped is a difficult stigma to overcome in Nigeria's highly religious and conservative society. Shekau had threatened in 2013 to kidnap women and girls if Nigeria's military did not release detained Boko Haram wives and children. The government freed them in May of that year as a goodwill gesture ahead of failed peace talks. Boko Haram has kidnapped hundreds more girls, boys, women and young men. Some have become sex slaves, while others are used as fighters, according to former captives. Nigerian opinion on negotiating with the extremists is mixed. Some say the group's crimes are too heinous to be forgiven: The 6-year-old Islamic uprising has killed more than 13,000 people and forced about 1.5 million from their homes. "A lot of people take a hard-line stance that you must never negotiate with a terrorist," said Sen. Chris Anyanwu. She called it a "very complex" issue, balancing the lives of more than 200 girls against the dangers of freeing extremists. The militants last year seized a large swath of northeast Nigeria and declared an Islamic caliphate. Nigeria and its neighbors deployed a multinational army that forced them out of towns and villages this year, but the bloodshed has risen at a fierce rate since Buhari's May 29 inauguration amid pledges to crush the insurgency. Associated Press writer Bashir Adigun contributed to this report from Abuja, Nigeria. 28 CONNECT 61 TWEET LINKEDIN 5 COMMENTEMAILMORE Copyright 2015 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1Mf22CM TOP VIDEOS

Article.title: Ireland legalizes gay marriage
Article.MainBody: FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Ireland legalizes gay marriage Drag queen and gay rights activist Rory O'Neill, also known by the stage name Panti, raises her arms on May 23 beside supporters for same-sex marriage at Dublin Castle as they waited for the result of the referendum.
